Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Collaborative Research: Integrated Biomimetic Block Copolymer Composite Membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512089/1512099
Phillip/Kumar
Notre Dame/Penn State

Mimicking biological membranes, which have developed innovative transport mechanisms through millennia of evolution, has gained increasing interest in recent years. In particular, biological membranes have embedded proteins that are capable of transporting chemical species into and out of cells efficiently and with exceptional selectivity. As such, developing membrane platforms that mimic the exquisite processes of biology provides a route toward performing many chemical separations that are critical to modern society (e.g., purification of drinking water). In order for these advanced membranes to make an impact on the chemical and biological separations the development of robust, high performance, composite membranes is required. These composite membranes comprise a biomimetic active layer containing membrane proteins supported mechanically by a highly-porous and permeable support layer. The generation of robust composite membranes, which realize the full potential of membrane proteins, requires that the active and support layers are integrated synergistically.

The goal of the proposed research project is to identify the key materials relationships that control the interplay between the nanostructures and chemistries of the copolymer supports and the biomimetic active layers in order to optimize the separations performance of composite biomimetic-block copolymer membranes (BBCMs). This novel class of membranes comprises a selective layer made from 2D crystals of membrane proteins and a support layer made from self-assembled copolymers.

The successful execution of this research project will deliver a transformative technology platform through an enhanced understanding of how to combine two self-assembled materials into a composite membrane relevant to a diversity of separations. Beyond the technical impact, a new generation of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students will be trained in a multi-disciplinary and collaborative setting. A summer camp for middle school students focused on water treatment will provide opportunities to bring this important application of membranes to a wider audience.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing biological inspired composite membranes for possible applications in a wide variety of fields including water purifications, food applications and pharmaceutical purification. The top layer of this membrane mimics the architecture of the cell membrane with a bilayer-like structure with embedded transport proteins. We focused on integration of this top ?active? layer with highly porous support layers ?either commercial or one where the pores were tailored to be highly dense and perfectly aligned and created using a process of ?self-assembly?.

 

Intellectual Merit. This project demonstrated that high-performance macro scale biomimetic membranes can be made using a careful optimization of the packing of proteins in the top active layer and design of the support layer of the membrane that provides bot stability and a low resistance to flow of the water filtered through the top layer. We also further showed that various pore sizes can be obtained for specific proteins used in the active layer by utilizing a optimization based protein redesign algorithm developed collaboratively. Similarly, the support block copolymer membrane has been optimized for selectivity using chemical modification and careful selection of chemical block. This GOALI project was highly collaborative with our industry partner, Applied Biomimetic, and has resulted in four invention disclosures, three of which are consideration by our industrial partner for licensing and further development and commercialization. Several peer-reviewed publications (10) have resulted from this work .

 

Broader Impacts. The project impacts the quest to solve the challenge of freshwater availability around the world by providing enabling technologies for upgrading marginal water sources, and reducing the cost of chemical and biopharmaceutical separations.  This work led to the training of four graduate students (two females), and a postdoctoral fellow, and with involvement from 2-3 undergraduate students. The work was presented at several conferences including at the American Institute of Chemical Engineers Conferences.  A Faraday Discussion related to the topic of the proposal was organized by the PI and resulted in several talks and peer-reviewed papers. Outreach efforts included 1) organizing a yearly week-long water camp for middle school students, the PI was camp director and the undergraduate and graduate researchers were camp and experiment mentors, 2) participation in an science outreach booth at the Central Pennsylvania Festival of the Arts for their Children?s day activities each summer.

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2018
Modified by: Manish Kumar
